title: Logothete
text:
Logothete (, "logothétēs", pl. λογοθέται, "logothétai"; Med. , pl. "logothetae"; ; ; ; , "logotet") was an administrative title originating in the eastern <a href="Roman%20Empire">Roman Empire</a>. In the middle and late <a href="Byzantine%20Empire">Byzantine Empire</a>, it rose to become a senior <a href="Byzantine%20aristocracy%20and%20bureaucracy">administrative title</a>, equivalent to a <a href="Minister%20%28government%29">minister</a> or <a href="secretary%20of%20state">secretary of state</a>. The title spread to other states influenced by Byzantine culture, such as <a href="Second%20Bulgarian%20Empire">Bulgaria</a>, <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Sicily">Sicily</a>, <a href="Serbia%20in%20the%20Middle%20Ages">Serbia</a>, and the <a href="Danubian%20Principalities">Danubian Principalities</a>.
Byzantine Empire.
Origin and development.
In <a href="Greek%20language">Greek</a>, "logothetēs" means "one who accounts, calculates or ratiocinates", literally "one who sets the word". The exact origin of the title is unclear; it is found in <a href="papyrus">papyri</a> and works of the <a href="Church%20Fathers">Church Fathers</a> denoting a variety of junior officials, mostly charged with fiscal duties. The ancestors of the middle Byzantine logothetes were the fiscal officials known as "<a href="rationalis">rationales</a>" during <a href="Late%20Antiquity">Late Antiquity</a>. The office dates back to at least the time of Emperor <a href="Septimius%20Severus">Septimius Severus</a> (), where a "<a href="procurator%20%28Roman%29">procurator</a> a rationibus" is attested. In late Roman times, the "rationales" were officials attached to the <a href="praetorian%20prefecture">praetorian prefecture</a>s and charged with supervising the state treasury and the emperor's private domains. The first notable official titled as a logothete was <a href="Marinus%20%28praetorian%20prefect%29">Marinus</a>, the future praetorian prefect and chief minister of Emperor <a href="Anastasius%20I%20%28emperor%29">Anastasius I</a> (). In the 6th century, under Emperor <a href="Justinian%20I">Justinian I</a> (), the logothetes gained in prominence and power, as they were placed in charge of the emperor's revenue-gathering measures and dispatched as fiscal agents to the provinces or accompanied military expeditions. They were allowed to keep a twelfth of the sums they would gather for the treasury, and some, such as the notorious <a href="Alexander%20%28discussor%29">Alexander "Scissors"</a>, amassed considerable fortunes in this way.
The major transformation of the office came in the early 7th century: during the <a href="Heraclian%20dynasty">Heraclian dynasty</a>, the administrative machinery of the state, inherited from the time of <a href="Diocletian">Diocletian</a> and <a href="Constantine%20the%20Great">Constantine the Great</a>, was thoroughly reformed. Thus the three chief financial "departments" of the old system, the Praetorian Prefecture, the <a href="comes%20sacrarum%20largitionum">Sacred Largesses</a> ("sacrae largitiones") and the <a href="comes%20rerum%20privatarum">Private Domains</a> ("res privata") were replaced by smaller specialized departments titled "logothesia" (sing. "logothesion") or "sekreta" (sing. "sekreton"). This process was the result of severe territorial loss and the need to rationalize revenue collection during the final <a href="Byzantine%E2%80%93Sassanid%20War%20of%20602%E2%80%93628">Byzantine–Persian War</a> and the <a href="Muslim%20conquests">Muslim conquests</a>, but had already been presaged by Emperor Justinian's reforms in the 6th century, when the "res privata", responsible for the managing of imperial estates, had been divided by kind into five separate departments. By the mid-7th century, the "sacrae largitiones" too disappeared altogether, while its various sections, as those of the praetorian prefecture, were separated and set up as autonomous departments, some of them headed by a logothete. These were under the supervision of the "<a href="sakellarios">sakellarios</a>", who functioned as a "general <a href="comptroller">comptroller</a> of finances", and ultimately of the emperor himself.
The first mention of a logothete in a senior position was the "most glorious logothete and <a href="patrikios">patrician</a>" Theodosios in 626, possibly either in charge of the "genikon" or the "stratiōtikon". Although the first concrete evidence for the existence of many of the subsequent offices is often of a much later date, the chief departments, the "genikon", the "(e)idikon", the "stratiōtikon" and the "dromos" were in place by the late 7th century. There were also logothetes in the church, assisting the patriarch and the <a href="metropolitan%20bishop">metropolitan bishop</a>s, while a "logothetēs tou praitoriou" was a senior official under the <a href="Eparch%20of%20Constantinople">Eparch of Constantinople</a>.
Under Emperor <a href="Alexios%20I%20Komnenos">Alexios I Komnenos</a> (), the logothete of the bureaux ("logothetēs tōn sekretōn") was instituted, who supervised all state departments, evolving eventually into the Grand Logothete ("megas logothetēs") of the late Byzantine Empire. By the <a href="Palaiologan%20period">Palaiologan period</a>, the various logothetes had vanished or were converted into purely honorary titles.
Logothetes outside Byzantium.
Serbia.
The title logotet () was used in <a href="Serbia%20in%20the%20Middle%20Ages">Serbia in the Middle Ages</a> since the rule of King <a href="Stefan%20Milutin">Stefan Milutin</a> (). Notable title-holders include <a href="Rajko%20%28logotet%29">Rajko</a>, <a href="Joanikije%20II">Joanikije</a>, <a href="Pribac%20Hrebeljanovi%C4%87">Pribac</a>, <a href="Gojko%20Mrnjav%C4%8Devi%C4%87">Gojko</a>, <a href="Vojihna">Voihna</a>, <a href="Pachomius%20the%20Serb">Pahomije</a> and <a href="Stefan%20Ratkovi%C4%87">Stefan Ratković</a>.
Sicily.
Holy Roman Emperor <a href="Emperor%20Otto%20III">Otto III</a> (), the son of the Byzantine princess <a href="Theophanu">Theophanu</a>, bestowed it on his chancellor, <a href="Leo%20of%20Vercelli">Leo of Vercelli</a> (999–1026). In the end, it only became firmly established in <a href="Sicily">Sicily</a>, where the logothete occupied the position of chancellor elsewhere, his office being equal if not superior to that of the "Magnus Cancellarius". Thus, the title was borne for example by <a href="Pietro%20della%20Vigna">Pietro della Vigna</a>, the all-powerful minister of Holy Roman Emperor <a href="Frederick%20II%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Frederick II</a> (), king of Sicily.
Romanian principalities.
The title was also borrowed in the internal organization of the medieval Romanian countries, <a href="Moldavia">Moldavia</a> and <a href="Wallachia">Wallachia</a>. In Moldavia, the Great Logothete ("mare logofăt") was the chief minister of the prince and head of the chancellery, while in Wallachia, he was the second-most senior member of the prince's council, after the <a href="ban%20%28title%29">ban</a>.

Modern Era.
Former <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">U.S. President</a> <a href="Theodore%20Roosevelt">Theodore Roosevelt</a> accused then-President <a href="Woodrow%20Wilson">Woodrow Wilson</a> of being a "Byzantine logothete." The epithet insinuated that, like pencil-pushing Byzantine logothetes, or administrators, Wilson was dillydallying by not declaring America's participation in <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>.
